Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Enhanced Pyroelectric and Electrocaloric Effects in Complex Oxide Thin Film Heterostructures
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Advances in the development of functional complex oxide materials have enabled many of the devices that are utilized on a daily basis from memories to actuators and beyond. This project is developing a deeper understanding of electro-thermal responses of materials and finding routes to enhance those effects to enable advanced thermal imaging (e.g., night-vision systems), waste-heat energy conversion for energy efficiency, novel electron emission for high-tech applications, and low-power solid-state cooling for nanoelectronics. This project is developing a design algorithm by which researchers can enhance the electric-field and temperature-dependent response of materials for such applications. Possible applications range from communications to data storage to logic to sensing devices. Fundamental research in these fields fosters the United States innovation in the growing green economy and high-technology spaces. The project includes research on the creation of new and complex materials, computational and theoretical approaches to materials design and optimization, and advanced characterization of materials properties. The project also promotes discovery and understanding at the K-12/undergraduate/graduate education levels by introducing students to advanced functional materials and broadening the participation (through personal interaction and recruitment) of underrepresented student groups in science and engineering careers.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: This project provides the one of the first studies of so-called magneto-electro-caloric and pyro-electric-magnetic effects, which make use of coupled order parameters in multiferroic/magneto-electrics. Additionally, the project is investigating frustrated ferroelectric order which should provide for large entropic changes with applied fields. The research project combines advances in phenomenological models, cutting-edge thin-film growth techniques (including pulsed-laser deposition and molecular beam epitaxy), and modern characterization techniques to develop a deeper understanding of the physics and thermodynamics of thermo-electrical responses (i.e., pyroelectric and electrocaloric effects) in complex oxide materials. This project is providing new insight into the underlying mechanisms of such thermo-electrical responses and seeking pathways to manipulate and control the temperature- and field-dependence of entropic changes in ferroic oxides. The overall goal of the project is to further the fundamental understanding of these effects, to develop predictive capabilities for responses in thin-film systems, and to probe the properties and ultimate performance of these materials to enable their use in devices. As part of this project, the researchers are creating and characterizing high-quality, heteroepitaxial, thin-film heterostructures and nanostructures of complex oxide materials and in turn, are investigating innovative approaches to enhance thermo-electrical responses in materials by exploring the temperature- and field-dependence of entropy in modern materials. The project is also providing fundamental insight into the physics of these effects by developing novel Ginzburg-Landau-Devonshire models of these thermodynamic properties that include effects from domain walls, polydomain structures, layered heterostructures, strain and composition gradients, and other features common in films. Finally, the project seeks to identify and overcome inadequacies in characterization of such properties, including the utilization of new techniques to provide the first direct measurement of such effects in thin films.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Advances in pyroelectric and electrocaloric materials could directly impact alternative energy production in the form of pyroelectric energy conversion, low-power solid-state cooling, and could represent a large market in high-technology applications. More globally, the advances in fundamental understandings of dielectric/ferroelectric/magnetoelectric response in materials has implications for a wide range of electroceramic applications (resonators, actuators, sensors, etc.) and next-generation memory, logic, and sensing devices under the generic guise of spintronics. Support of fundamental research in these fields places the United States in good standing to innovate in the coming years. By understanding the connection between the processing and properties of next-generation, oxide-based thermo-electrical materials and routes to utilize the unique functionalities of these materials for enhanced responses, this program aims to develop the fundamental tools by which we can leverage these materials for future applications. These applications would have direct impact on improving social and economic conditions, in lessening our impact on the environment, and much more.

In this project, we have produced outcomes addressing a numeber of core aspects of this program, including:

  1. New understanding about the physics and thermodynamics of thermo-electrical responses (i.e., pyroelectric and electrocaloric effects) in complex-oxide materials. This includes new insights into the nature of field-based response in these materials including identifying a new form of domain wall response, demonstrating ways to decouple piezoelectric/pyroelectric and dielectric response, and deterministically tune strain states in materials. In turn, the project also provided new pathways to manipulate and control such effects.
  2. New predictive capabilities for these responses in thin-film systems based on our deeper understanding of the effects.
  3. New methodologies to probe the properties and ultimate performance of these materials including the development of new measurement modalities.
  4. Demonstration of the potential of these materials for devices and applications ranging from thermal imaging/sensing to waste heat energy conversion to solid state cooling to electron emission and beyond.

More broadly for other disciplines and the broader scientific community, this project has produced:

  1. Advances that inform the development of new models, cutting-edge thin-film growth techniques, and modern characterization techniques can be applied to countless numbers of thin-film systems and to the study of a wide array of properties.
  2. New understanding of coupling in multiferroic/magnetoelectric heterostructures which has implications for memory, logic, and sensing applications.
  3. Understanding of frustrated ferroelectric phases which impact the greater field of ferroelectric physics and dielectric materials and has direct implications for high-performance dielectrics, piezoelectrics, and ferroelectrics.
  4. Advances in modeling capabilities which have implications across the board for all ferroic systems as the techniques developed here can be applied to make more realistic 3D, polydomain models of materials. Such models can be applied to address a range of topics from dielectric response to piezoelectricity to ferroelectricity and could have potential to impact applications ranging from capacitors and insulators to actuators and sensors to memories and logics.

Finally, the program has made marked broader impacts on next-generation scientists and engineers including:

  1. Training students and researchers some of the most poorly developed, but technologically relevant fields of study in functional materials as well as in the synthesis of complex materials – a key skill-set needed to support next-generation technology and scientific advancement in the US. The training imparted to graduate and undergraduate students prepares them for cutting-edge research and technology jobs in an array of fields and will provide the US with the human infrastructure for exciting and pertinent fields.
  2. Research experience and mentorship aimed at providing students from underrepresented groups a first research experience and broadening their participation in STEM. This experience instills in those students a personal connection to the topics and promoted retention in science and engineering.
  3. Direct, one-on-one mentorship in scientific research methods, scientific writing and presentation, and other professional skill-sets essential for success at the next level.
  4. Scientific discoveries in this project supported the development of a number of commerical applications from waste heat energy conversion to solid state cooling for microelectronics to electron emission and beyond.
  5. Support for budding industries in the US including the PI interacting with start-up companies as a scientific advisor to promote dissemination of knowledge and development of high-tech jobs in the US.
  6. Incorporation of new mateirals into the education and outreach programs that have touch hundreds of students and community members.
